Caption: Figure 1: The above frames illustrate the design alternatives we evaluated in this study. Frame A follows the traditional storyline design where the y-coordinate encodes interaction via proximity. Frame B is a our layered design where the y-coordinate encodes the interaction context and has a consistent meaning over time.
Table 1: Interaction Groups (from Tanahashi et al. [31])

Figure 2: In this screenshot of the storyline tool used in our design study the user has zoomed in on a particular day, ﬁltered out some employees, based on type, and selected a bundle of individuals during lunch time. The map shows where they left from (GASTech) and where they went to (a cafe to the northwest). Frame A (Breadcrumbs): Our tool lets the user explore the data at different time granularities. The breadcrumbs show what time ranges the user has zoomed into. Frame B (Controls): The user can change the selection, the visible storylines, and the time granularity using the controls toolbar. Frame C (Storyline Visualization): Entities’ similarity over time are shown with the storyline visualization. In this view, the aesthetic design alternative is shown. When the layered design alternative is used, it replaces this view but the remainder of the interface remains the same. Frame D (Map): The locations and trajectories of individuals are plotted on the map to provide geospatial context. Frame E (Entities): The user can select items on the map, storyline visualization, entities list, or legend. Selection is linked across all of these views. Frame F (Legend): This shows the breakdown of visible entities by employment type, and shows the relationship between the storyline color and the employment type.

Figure 3: This shows two comparisons of the storyline design alternatives. For each example, the aesthetic layout is placed above the layered layout. The callouts with blue backgrounds were added for illustrative purposes and are not part of the user interface. Frame A shows interactions at a coarse grained time scale over a two week period. This is the initial overview storyline view that users ﬁrst see in the interface, and the two alternative designs appear fairly similar to each other. Frame B shows interactions at a ﬁne grained time scale as individuals are leaving GASTech after work. The aesthetic layout allows the viewer to judge the volume of individuals in interaction groups more easily than the layered layout (the reader should compare B1.1 to B2.1). However, the layered layout accentuates an individual who changes locations around 17:20. In the aesthetic layout the line remain straight (the reader should compare B1.2 to B2.2).
Figure 4: On a per-question basis, for many questions the mean precision and recall for the layered design is higher.
Table 3: A list of user study task areas and corresponding questions. Some questions were omitted after a post-hoc analysis.

Figure 6: Participants showed little differences across conditions in subjective responses (on a 5 point Likert scale) taken during exit interviews. However, no participant gave the layered design alternative the highest rating for either overall or storyline utility.
Figure 5: For both metrics there is a moderately signiﬁcant differ- ence (p < .05) between design alternatives for the “overview” task. Participants using the layered design performed better.
Figure 8: Seriation of G f low representing ﬂow between interaction contexts produces orderings with reduced crossings.

Figure 7: An overview of the aesthetic layout algorithm. Size encodes the number of storylines within interaction groups. Between (a) and (b) an ordering of vertices is found to reduce crossings. Red edges in (c) show pairs of interaction groups that were aligned to reduce wiggles.

Figure 9: We redesigned our layout algorithm based on lessons learned from our study. The y-coordinate encodes the interaction context (the location of the interaction) and is consistent over time. Lines within interaction groups are not over-plotted, and crossings are further reduced.
